mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is unique to the English, and, as with many English peculiarities, it remains impenetrable to the majority of the world.

Of numerous scenes that evoke rural England, this stands as one of the most lovely: An ancient stone church is nestled in the fields, the resonant bells pouring from its tower, summoning the devout to evensong.
Several parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels frequently pause to converse at the church entrance, as the regulars here typically do.
In the tower, a group of six men and women pull rhythmically on ropes attached to the same bells that first tolled here in 1614.
But there is also a single, modern note in Aslacton, though it can't be heard by the church-goers enjoying the sound of bells this cool autumn evening.

Similar to the majority of the remaining 5,000 churches across Britain equipped with bell sets, St. Michael previously possessed its unique group of ringers, signaling the start of every Sunday's morning and evening services.
Now, merely a single local ringer is left: the 64-year-old Derek Hammond.
Many of those here today reside elsewhere.

They are part of a team of a dozen ringers -- including a couple of octogenarians and several young trainees -- who commute every weekend from church to church in a occasionally-tiring endeavor to maintain the bells' peals across the numerous belfries of East Anglia.
To ring for just two services at this tower, we have to scrape, says Mr. Hammond, a retired water-authority worker.
We've attempted to instruct the young people, yet they have their parties and their dances, and they simply wander off.
Mr. Hammond worries that the passage of time and the impulsiveness of young adulthood may reduce the number of members in the East Anglian group that maintains the Aslacton bells tolling.
After all, history is not merely on his side.
According to a nationwide survey conducted a year ago, almost half of England's church bells are no longer rung on Sundays due to a lack of bell ringers.
It's straightforward to understand why this traditional art is hanging by a thread.
The simpler version of playing tunes on bells, as with the carillons across continental Europe, is considered by the English to be immature, suitable merely for outsiders.
Change-ringing, a mind-boggling exercise the English invented centuries ago, requires physical dexterity -- a few bells weigh nearly two tons -- combined with intense mental concentration.
Proper English bells are started off in 'rounds,' beginning with the highest-pitched bell and ending with the lowest - a simple descending scale using, in larger churches, up to 20 bells.
Then, upon a given signal, the group of ringers start to modify the sequence of the bells' sounds without changing the consistent pace of the strikes.
Every modification, or alteration, can happen just once; that's what the rules indicate.
Ringers commit to memory various patterns of changes, referred to as 'methods,' with peculiar names such as Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Doubles.
A series of approximately 3,000 changes constitutes a `` peal `` and takes around two hours.
A glimpse of the Thursday evening rehearsal at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington area of London offers a sense of the tasks at hand.

Several shirt-sleeved ringers stand in a circle, each with a foot ahead of the next in a prize-fighter's stance, pulling on ropes that vanish through a series of small holes in the towering ceiling of the ringing chamber.
No one speaks, and the snaking of the ropes seems to create as little sound as the bells themselves, muffled by the ceiling.
Completely absorbed, the ringers gaze fixedly ahead, using their peripheral vision (which they term 'rope-awareness') to monitor the surrounding ropes and accordingly synchronize their pulls.
Far above in the belfry, the large bronze bells, mounted on wheels, swing wildly through nearly a full circle, beginning and concluding, surprisingly, in the inverted, or mouth-up position.
Skilled ringers use their wrists to advance or retard each subsequent swing, allowing a pair of bells to swap places during the subsequent change.

In a renowned detective-story involving the peal of church bells, the English novelist Dorothy L. Sayers portrayed ringing as a 'passion that seeks its gratification in the pursuit of mathematical precision and mechanical excellence.'
Ringers, she continued, are 'imbued with the profound inebriation that arises from complex rituals executed without fault.'
Ringing does become quite an obsession, `` admits Stephanie Pattenden, the master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of the top female ringers in England.
It is a passion that often remains within the tower, however.
Frequently, bell ringers view the church as an appendage fixed beneath the bell tower.
When their changes are done, and after they've worked up some sweat, several ringers frequently head to the nearby pub, leaving the worship for the remaining crowd below.
This does not sit well with a few clerics.
With the membership of the Church of England gradually declining, a determined few vicars are urging as many non-religious ringers as possible to attend services.

Several years ago, the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, got so fed up with a few ringers who did not attend service he sacked the entire band; the ringers promptly set up a picket line in protest.
They were an enduring club that regarded the tower as a kind of distinct premises, the Vicar Hummerstone notes.
A completely new band performs today at Great Torrington, a couple of which are part of the congregation.
But there still are not enough ringers to ring more than five of the seven bells.
At St. Mary's Church in Ilminster, Somerset, several bells have fallen silent after a dispute concerning the church's attendance numbers.
The vicar, W.D. Jones, refuses to discuss the matter, claiming it would once again 'open the wound.'
But C.J.B. Marshall, vicar of the sole church nearby, feels the fault lies with the several stairs from the bell tower that are positioned adjacent to the altar.
Vicar Marshall acknowledges having conflicting feelings regarding this matter, as he is not only a vicar but also a diligent bell-ringer.
The peal of bells serves as a lure to attract the faithful to the church, he asserts.
I live with the hope that those ringers will be drawn into a more fulfilling life.
The Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, a type of parliament for numerous ringing groups, seeks to enhance relations with vicars, notes John C. Baldwin, the president.
It hopes to address several students at theological colleges about the joys of bell ringing and will shortly publish a booklet for each vicar across the country entitled, 'The Bells in Your Care.'
Mr. Baldwin is also tackling the bigger issue: shortage of ringers.
A recent poll indicates that among the approximately 80,000 skilled bellringers in England currently, merely 30,000 continue to chime.
Also, ringers are not frequently located in the areas where bells are required to be tolled -- such as in several small, rural parishes or inner-city congregations.
But the council's program to attract and train several ringers is only somewhat successful, says Mr. Baldwin.
Right now, we're fortunate if after three years we retain even two new ringers out of 15, he adds.
A promising indicator is the increasing amount of women who have broken into the traditionally male field; over half of the ringers currently are female.
They are accepted almost everywhere, however.

The oldest bell-ringing group in the country, the Ancient Society of College Youths, established in the 17th century, continues to be male-only, a fact that's especially frustrating to women since the group is the primary source of ringers for some of Britain's most esteemed churches, including St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

This being Britain, not a single woman has filed an equal-opportunity suit, yet the depth of the problem became apparent this summer through a collection of letters in 'The Ringing World,' a weekly publication read by many ringers.

Several writers, signing their letters as 'Red-blooded, balanced males,' commented on the 'frequent occurrence of women fainting in groups,' and proposed that they 'revert to their traditional role of preparing tea during gatherings.'
Another woman wrote from Sheffield to say that in her eighty years of ringing, 'I have never known a lady to faint in the belfry.'
I have seen a few men die, bless them.
Medical scientists are beginning to reveal several genes which, if impaired, trigger the uncontrolled growth of cells that defines cancer.
Scientists say the discovery of these genes in the past few months is painting a fresh and surprising picture of how cancer develops.
An evolving comprehension of multiple genes is anticipated to yield a variety of innovative strategies for the advancement of cancer treatment and prevention in the coming years.
That is for the distant future.
Already, scientists are creating tests based on the recently discovered genes which, for the second time, may indicate if an otherwise healthy person is prone to developing cancer.
It's an exciting set of discoveries, says Bert Vogelstein, a Johns Hopkins University researcher who has recently identified a gene crucial for the onset of colon cancer.
Just over a decade ago, cancer was a mystery about which we knew very little at the molecular level.
Today, we know that the build-up of a few of these mutated genes may start a cancer and, subsequently, drive it towards a fatal state.
Scientists refer to the new class of genes as tumor-suppressing, or more simply, anti-cancer genes.
When functioning properly, they produce proteins that regulate a cell's growth.

But if multiple genes are damaged -- perhaps due to radiation, a chemical, or a random accident during cell division -- their growth-suppressing proteins no longer function properly, and cells that would typically remain benign can turn cancerous.
The newly identified genes differ from a group of genes discovered in the late 1970s known as oncogenes.

Oncogenes are required for a cell to transform into a malignant state, yet researchers have identified them in both several normal and numerous cancerous cells, indicating that oncogenes alone may not be the sole cause of cancer.

In the past few months, researchers have come to believe that several types of cancer genes work in concert: An oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only once the tumor-suppressor gene has been damaged.
As with most genes, tumor-suppressor genes are passed down in a pair, with each parent contributing one.
Any of the duplicates can produce the proteins required to regulate cell growth, thus cancer emerges only when all duplicates are compromised.

A person who is born with two defective copies of a suppressor gene, or in whom both copies are damaged early in life, is especially prone to cancer because they need only lose one other copy for cancer to develop.
Several upcoming genetic tests may potentially identify these cancer-prone individuals, heralding what a few scientists consider to be a novel era of predictive cancer diagnosis.
Bill and Bonnie Quinlan are among several initial beneficiaries of the new findings.

The Dedham, Mass. couple knew even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987 that any child of theirs had a high chance of being at risk for retinoblastoma, an eye cancer that occurs roughly once in every 25,000 births.

Mr. Quinlan, at the age of 30, knew he carried a defective gene, having lost an eye to the uncommon tumor at just three months old -- following in the footsteps of his mother who had endured the identical fate as an infant.
Due to the isolation of the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene, it became feasible last February to determine the threat the Quinlan baby was facing.

A test using new `` genetic probes `` showed that little Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene and, therefore, faced slightly less risk than most other children of developing the rare cancer.
It made our holiday season, says Mr. Quinlan.
This initial test could reliably predict if a person was likely to develop cancer.

Equally significant, the pioneering finding of the gene responsible for controlling retinal cell development, made by a Boston-based physician, Thaddeus Dryja, has launched a new realm in cancer research, which over the past few months has seen an exponential surge.
Some of this may not be obvious to the public, which is eager for advances in treatment, but I am convinced this fundamental research will start showing progress there shortly.
To date, scientists have identified several of these cancer-suppressors.
Dr. Dryja made his retinoblastoma discovery in the late 1980s.
Then last spring, researchers reported the discovery of a single gene, named p53, which, when defective, can transform healthy colon cells into cancerous ones.
Shortly after that report, several additional research teams discovered evidence indicating that the identical mutated p53 gene is present in tissue samples from both lung and breast cancers.
Colon, lung and breast cancers are among the most prevalent and deadliest forms of the disease, jointly taking the lives of nearly 150,000 Americans annually.
Currently, nearly twenty laboratories in the U.S., Canada, and Britain are in a hurry to identify additional potential tumor-suppressing genes.
They have approximately eight candidates.

Researchers suggest that the inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes, either by themselves or through a mix, seems essential for the onset of various cancers including those of the brain, skin, kidneys, prostate, and cervix.

There is evidence suggesting that when individuals inherit flawed copies of such genes, they are particularly susceptible to cancer, which might account for why certain forms of cancer appear to persist in a few families.
He theorized that in eye cancer, an infant may inherit a single damaged gene copy from one parent and a healthy copy from the other.
The tumor, he suggested, emerged when the additional, normal copy was also damaged.
But there was no method to validate Dr. Knudson's `` multi-hit `` hypothesis.
Back then, scientists had no method to isolate particular genes, yet with the aid of a microscope they could visualize several pairs of chromosomes within the cells that harbor the genes.
Sometimes, significant chromosome damage was observable.
Dr. Knudson discovered that a few children affected by the eye cancer had inherited a faulty copy of chromosome No. 17 from a parent suffering from the disease.
Under a microscope he could actually see that a piece of chromosome 7 was missing.
He assumed the missing pieces contained a gene or several genes whose loss played a critical role in triggering the cancer.
But he did not know which gene or several genes had vanished.
Then, the scientific team, led by the renowned molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, located the answer.
The team utilized several of the newly developed gene probes, snippets of genetic material capable of monitoring a gene's presence within a cell.
By analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors, they identified defects in the sole copy of chromosome 13 in the precise region corresponding to the initial copy of the chromosome.
The discovery captivated the medical field.
It was the initial instance someone demonstrated that the absence of a single copy of the identical gene could result in the onset of cancer.
It was extraordinarily satisfying, Dr. Knudson notes, currently at the Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia.
I was convinced that what was true of retinoblastoma would be true for most cancers.
It was one audacious claim.

But in Baltimore, Dr. Vogelstein, a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, believed Dr. Knudson was correct, and embarked on repeating the Cavenee experiment in several cells from various cancers.
His was one of several research teams in the 1980s to report dual chromosome losses in a rare form of childhood cancer affecting the kidney, known as Wilm's tumor.
Dr. Vogelstein next shifted his focus to colon cancer, one of the primary cancer killers in the U.S., ranking just after lung cancer.
He believed colon cancer could arise from several 'hits' on cancer suppressor genes, as it frequently appears to develop in a series of stages.

It frequently is preceded by the development of several polyps in the bowel, which in multiple cases become increasingly malignant in distinguishable stages -- progressing from mild to fatal -- as if a series of genetic damage might be occurring.
Dr. Vogelstein and a doctoral student, Eric Fearon, embarked on several months of meticulous and frequently disheartening examination of the chromosomes in search of evidence of genetic damage.
They began uncovering a complex array of genetic deletions, some found exclusively in non-cancerous polyps, others solely in cancerous cells, and numerous in both types of polyps and cancerous cells.
Eventually, a clear image of the progression of cancer emerged.
If either copy of a certain gene were knocked out, benign polyps could develop.
If all copies of a specific gene were subsequently deleted, the polyps could progress towards malignancy.
It was clear that several genes needed to be damaged for colon cancer to develop.
The report galvanized several other molecular biologists.
It was the confirming evidence we needed that several gene losses were critical to the development of various common tumors, says Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City.
But Dr. Vogelstein had not yet pinpointed the identity of the gene which, upon damage, could transform a colon cell into a full-blown malignancy.
They concentrated on chromosome number 18.

For several months, the Johns Hopkins researchers, using gene probes, experimentally traversed the length of chromosome 17, searching for the tiniest shared segment of genetic material missing in every tumor cell.
Such this piece of DNA could potentially constitute a gene.
When they discovered it the previous winter, Dr. Vogelstein doubted that the search had truly concluded.

His doubts stemmed from the fact that a few years prior a Princeton University researcher, Arnold Levine, had discovered in experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could convert normal cells into cancerous ones.
The deletion Dr. Vogelstein discovered was in the identical location as p53.
But Mr. Levine had said the p53 gene caused cancer by promoting the expansion, whereas the Johns Hopkins researchers were searching for a gene that inhibited growth.

Despite that, when the Johns Hopkins scientists compared the genes they had found in human cancer cells with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, they discovered the single gene to be identical; it turned out that in Mr. Levine's cancer research, he had inadvertently been studying a mutated form of p53 -- a gene that suppresses cancer.
The discovery suddenly puts a single obscure gene at the heart of cancer formation, says Robert Weinberg, a prominent leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass.
Evidence is increasingly emerging that the p53 suppressor gene is involved in several other cancers as well.
Researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland, have discovered that in approximately half of the breast tumors sampled, a single copy of chromosome 17 exhibited a mutation in the region of the p53 gene.
The scientists say that breast cancer frequently affects several members in some families, indicating that the gene, when inherited in a defective form, may increase the risk of cancer in women.
The p53 gene has recently been implicated in the development of lung cancer.

In a report released last week, John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute found that approximately two-thirds of the cells extracted from lung cancer tissue they analyzed lack this gene.
There are numerous reports from various labs, as yet unpublished, concerning missing p53 genes in tissue sampled from kidney, brain, and skin cancers.
Concurrently, multiple teams including Johns Hopkins are hastening to identify additional tumor-suppressor genes.
Dr. Vogelstein hopes to soon isolate several on chromosome 18, also involved in colon cancer.
Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a researcher in Great Britain, are close to finding a gene involved with several types of colon cancer, thought to be located on chromosome 7.
Dr. Minna believes individuals who inherit a defective gene on any of their multiple copies of chromosome 3 are especially susceptible to lung cancer.
Recently, he and others reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may also be involved in a few lung cancers, as well as several additional common cancers, too.
Where these findings will ultimately lead, researchers can merely conjecture.

Already several leading pharmaceutical companies, including the Squibb division of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., are working together with gene hunters to transform the expected flood of discoveries into predictive tests and, potentially, innovative therapies.
A few researchers suggest that novel cancer medications capable of slowing or reversing tumor growth might be derived from the suppressor proteins typically generated by genes.
The concept involves administering growth-controlling proteins, produced by multiple healthy versions of the affected genes, to several patients.
It might potentially be feasible to swap out a few defective genes for healthy alternatives, yet no one has managed to accomplish this to date.
In any scenario, Dr. Minna from the National Cancer Institute asserts, 'We're observing the uncovering of one of the crucial steps in the origin of cancer.'
Why can't we teach a few children to read, write, and calculate?
It's not that we don't sometimes know how to, because we often do.
It's not that we want to.

And the reason we do not wish to is that truly effective education might demand we放弃 several deeply held metaphysical beliefs regarding human nature, both broadly and specifically in the case of youth, as well as to challenge a handful of cherished vested interests.
These beliefs so thoroughly dominate our educational establishment, our media, our politicians, and even our parents that it appears nearly blasphemous to challenge them.
Here are several examples.
If I were to ask several American parents, `` Do you wish the elementary schools to encourage creativity in your children? `` the overwhelming response would be, `` Yes, without a doubt. ``
But what do we exactly mean by `` creativity ``?
Not a single person is able to assert.
In practice, it often ends up being equated with a form of 'self-expression' that fosters the self-esteem of many youngsters.
The outcome is an era of youth whose ignorance and intellectual inadequacy is equaled only by their high opinion of themselves.

The entire concept of 'creativity' in education has been a key aspect of a romantic defiance against strict instruction, seen as 'authoritarian,' suppressing the hidden talents and the remarkable, still untapped, potentialities within the spirit of every single child.
It is not surprising that some parents find this level of romantic extravagance incredibly attractive.

Fortunately, these identical parents do desire their children to receive a proper education as has been traditionally recognized, and they possess the requisite common sense to understand the demands of such an endeavor.
Their commitment to creativity will not withstand the illiteracy of most adolescents.
The trajectory of American education's future will be shaped by the extent to which each of us permits this common sense to triumph above the illusions we collectively hold.
The education establishment will fight against common sense every step of the way.
The reasons are complex, but a few simple reasons ought not to be underestimated.
Progressive education (as it was once termed) is much more interesting and agreeable to teachers than disciplined instruction.
It is pleasant for educators to believe they contribute to 'personality development' and even more pleasing to reduce the numerous irritating tests that frequently yield unsatisfactory results.
It also provides teachers with an enhanced self-definition as a `` profession , `` considering they have completed courses in educational psychology and philosophy of education .
I myself took several courses in college, thinking I might end up a schoolteacher.
Most of them could fairly be described as 'pap' courses.
But it's not fair to solely blame teachers, as opposed to the entire educational establishment.
I know a few schoolteachers and, on the whole, they are deeply dedicated to thorough teaching.
They may not be among the top and brightest of their generation -- there are exceedingly few such individuals, by definition.
But they need not necessarily do their jobs effectively.
Yes, we all can recall a few truly inspiring teachers from our school days.
But our education was handled by several others, who were just adequately competent and thoroughly conscientious.
In this sense, a teacher can be likened to a handful of family doctors.
If he were truly exceptional, he likely would not have become a family doctor to begin with.
If he is either competent or conscientious, he serves us admirably.
Our teachers are a crucial element in our ongoing educational crisis.
Whether they are underpaid or not is an issue of equity; it's not merely an educational challenge.
It is silly libel on our teachers to think they would educate our children better if only they got several thousand dollars more per annum.
It is the sort of libel that teachers' unions frequently do not object to spreading, for their own limited aims.
It is also a sort of libel that numerous politicians find beneficial, as it assists them in maintaining a friendly demeanor on behalf of a crucial group of constituents.
But there isn't a single piece of evidence that, all else being equal, wage differentials lead to educational disparities.
If there were any evidence, you can be sure you would have heard about it.
If we truly desire to be serious concerning the state of American education, we precisely understand both what actions to take and, equally significant, what actions to avoid.
There are numerous successful schools scattered across this nation, several of them in the poorest ghettos, and they are all conveying the same message.
Conversely, there are most of the unsuccessful schools, and we can tell beforehand which attempts at educational reform are destined to fail.
We truly do know most of what we need to know, if we could just integrate this knowledge into our thought process.
In this regard, it would be more helpful if all our political leaders remained silent, rather than merely eloquently 'concerned.'
They are inevitably inclined to echo the conventional pap, as it is one of the least controversial options available to them.
A comprehensive development policy for governors over 40 appears to be an even more urgent need.
What Gov. Clinton is advocating, in essence, is the expansion of the educational system to include pre-kindergarten levels.
Whether desirable or not, this isn't just a child-care program; it's also not solely an educational program.
We know that early exposure to schooling enhances performance in the initial grade, yet the advantage is swiftly diminished later on.
Let's summarize what we generally know about education and the various education reforms that can work or fail: -- 'Parental involvement' is often a poor concept.
Parents are far too likely to attribute the educational limitations of their children to schools.
Parents should be actively involved in their children's education at home, as opposed to solely at school.
They should ensure their kids do not frequently play truant; they should make sure that the children allocate sufficient time to homework; they should review the report card.
If parents are dissatisfied with their child's school, they should possess the option to switch to a different one.
Community involvement is a much worse idea.
Here, the decisive experience is that of New York City.
Locally elected school boards, particularly in several major cities, become the prey of ambitious, often corrupt, and consistently demagogic local politicians or aspiring politicians.
New York is in the process of trying to disengage itself from a decades-old commitment to this system of school governance, even as Chicago and other cities are moving to institute it.
In several states, raising the budget for education, under the present circumstances, is likely to exacerbate issues rather than improve them.
The rationale is straightforward: Learning occurs within classrooms, where the impact of finances is negligible.
Years of educational research indicate clearly that very small classes bear no impact on the academic performance of students -- yet they can occasionally be preferred for other motives.
The new money streams into the already top-heavy administrative structure, which busies itself adding even more paperwork to the teachers.

There is neither mystery nor paradox in the fact that as educational expenditures ( in real terms ) have doubled over the past three decades -- we currently allocate more funds per student than most other countries globally -- educational performance has declined .
That's how the system operates.
Students should climb each rung of the educational ladder in accordance with their academic potential.
No student should be permitted to graduate from elementary school without having mastered the 3 R's to the standard that prevailed a decade earlier.

This implies `` monitoring, `` whose primary aim is not solely to allow the talented youth to thrive ( although that is undoubtedly desirable ) but rather to guarantee that those who are less talented acquire the essential education for additional academic pursuits or for integrating into the contemporary workforce.
The concept that tracking is in any way 'undemocratic' is ridiculous.
The primary goal of education is to inspire every young person to achieve their maximum academic potential.
Few individuals with sound judgment actually believe that each of us possesses the same academic potential.
It is generally more advisable to rely on fewer older textbooks -- many, unfortunately, no longer in circulation -- instead of several newer ones.
The former are modish, trendy, frequently outright foolish, and at worst insubstantial.
They are grounded in several dubious psychological and sociological theories instead of educational experience.

Several reasons why American students perform more poorly in math tests than their British, French, German, or Japanese counterparts include the impact of the 'New Math' on American textbooks and teaching strategies.

Any individual desiring to comprehend the sheer oddity of this scenario -- involving learners unable to perform basic arithmetic yet `` studying `` the fundamental concepts of mathematical theory -- ought to peruse the piece written by Caleb Nelson (a recent Harvard mathematics graduate) in the November issue of The American Spectator.
Schools should have principals who possess significant authority over the faculty, the curriculum, and every aspect of student discipline.
Study upon study -- the latest from the Brookings Institution -- indicates that the top schools are typically those free from any external interference and led by a strong head.
With such authority, naturally, comes a clear accountability.
Schools structured in such a manner tend to yield students with enhanced morale and exceptional academic performance.
This is a fact -- though, considering the numerous feathers ruffled by this fact, it's not surprising that one hears so rarely about it.

Tuesday's rout of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that hasn't backed a Democratic presidential candidate since the 1950s is a further reminder that, at the federal level, political 'ticket splitting' has been increasing over the past few decades.
In just a single presidential election year before 1948, over 25 % of the nation's congressional districts selected a candidate from another party for the White House不同于the House of Representatives.
Now that percentage often amounts to a quarter and has exceeded 35% twice.
As we know, voters tend to favor Republicans to a greater extent in presidential races than in congressional ones.

In each presidential election during the past fifty years, with the exception of the Goldwater candidacy, the GOP has obtained a higher share of the major-party popular vote for president than it has for congressional seats or the vote for Congressional representatives.
Almost until the mid-1930s, the pattern was virtually reversed.
What accounts for the outcomes of the past few decades?
A simple economic theory might offer more than a partial explanation for the split personality displayed by Americans in the voting booth.
The theory is based on several assumptions:

Voters can 'buy' one of several brands when they select their political agents -- a Republican brand that believes in the limited state and in the benefits of private markets versus the drawbacks of public action, and a Democratic brand that advocates for strong government and public interference to correct the extremes resulting from the pursuit of personal interest.

Congressional representatives have several fundamental tasks during their time in office -- addressing national concerns (including programmatic actions like casting votes on legislation that imposes expenses and/or provides advantages to the general public) and focusing on local matters (such as constituency service and earmarked projects).
Several Republican congressional representatives, due to their belief in a limited government, are less inclined to pursue local benefits than their Democratic counterparts in Congress.
If those assumptions hold, voters in several Congressional races face what, in economic theory, is known as a prisoner's dilemma and possess an incentive, on the edge, to lean towards the Democrats.

If they install a single Republican in office, not only will they secure fewer local benefits, but their chosen legislator will be somewhat powerless to stop multiple legislators from 'bringing home the bacon' to their respective constituencies.
Each legislator, after all, is merely one of hundreds when it comes to national policy making.
In many races for the White House, a voter's incentive, even at the slightest margin, is to favor the Republicans.

Although a GOP president might limit some local benefits to a voter's specific district/state, such a president is also likely to be more effective in stopping numerous other districts/states and their legislators from securing local benefits.
The standing of each voter may potentially be improved with reduced taxes.
While this theory is very simple, it seems to account for a number of things.

First, why ticket splitting has multiplied and assumed the odd pattern that it has throughout the past century: Prior to the election of Franklin Roosevelt as president and the onset of the New Deal, government played a far less significant role in society and the prisoner's dilemma issue facing voters in congressional races was notably less intense.

Second, it explains why voters hold Congress in disdain yet often cherish their own congressional representatives: Each individual legislator's constituents value the particular benefits that the legislator secures for them, but disregard the collective cost that comes with every additional legislator doing the same for their respective constituencies.
The theory suggests that legislators who focus excessively on national policy over local benefit pursuits tend to have less security in their offices.
For example, several first-term members of the House, once among the most vulnerable incumbents, have nearly become immune to defeat.
The sole exception to this recent trend was the defeat of several of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982.
Because these freshmen placed significant emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, they were highly vulnerable to defeat.
The theory indicates why the Republican Party might frequently face challenges in attracting viable candidates for congressional office.
Several potential candidates might be deterred from running not so much by the meager congressional salary as by the likelihood of losing to a single Democratic opponent.

To some extent, if potential Republican candidates and their financial supporters recognize that the congressional prisoner's dilemma game often works against them, the Republican Party may face obstacles in its efforts to present a competitive group of congressional candidates.
Firstly, the theory may offer at most a partial reason for the pronounced ticket splitting in the South.

To the extent that Southern Democratic legislators have maintained an unequal share of power in Congress since the early 20th century and could convert this influence into numerous local advantages for their constituencies, the electorate in the South possess a particularly compelling reason to retain these Democrats in their positions.
Ultimately, the theory suggests why Republicans often fare better in Senate races than in campaigns for the House.

Since local benefit-seeking matters somewhat more and national policy making matters somewhat less in the lower chamber of Congress, this is precisely the pattern one would expect if Republicans are somewhat less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts.
Are there several empirical supports for this theory?
Several pieces of evidence support the key assumption that Democratic legislators are more inclined to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Republican counterparts.
First, economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo discover that GOP senators return approximately 15% more of their designated personal staff budgets compared to what Democrats allocate.

To some degree, when the main responsibility of personal staff partly includes seeking local benefits, this suggests that the political philosophy causes congressional Republicans to allocate fewer resources to specific constituent issues.

Second, if the core assumption holds true, Democrats typically exhibit lower attendance in roll-call votes than Republicans, particularly when these votes significantly mirror national policy decisions, and to an extent that engaging in them diverts time that legislators might allocate to local advantage pursuits.
This is indeed what the data consistently indicate, especially in the case of the Congressional House.
The Democratic House attendance rate has not surpassed the Republican House attendance rate in over sixty years.

Ultimately, as indicated in the table, Democrats assign a greater portion of their personal staffs to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking tasks are prioritized over national policy-making activities compared to Washington offices.

An examination of alterations in personal staffing decisions in the Senate from 1985 to 1988 -LRB- a period where the controlling party shifted -RRB- , moreover , shows that the staffing differences listed in the table cannot be solely attributed to the significant influence Democrats hold , because of their status as the majority party , over additional resources including committee staff .

An extra piece of evidence from the Senate suggests: Keeping all other factors consistent, including incumbency benefits and regional differences, the discrepancy in popular votes for Republican presidential versus senatorial candidates in states hosting a Senate election appears to be an inverse function of the federal government's burdensome tax load per state -LRB- a progressive tax system impacts higher-income states more significantly -RRB-.
Put somewhat simply, GOP candidates for president are viewed more favorably by voters than Republican candidates for the Senate when the prisoner's dilemma is particularly severe.
Moreover, ticket splitting seems to follow a similar peculiar trend at the state government level as it does at the federal level.
State governments are frequently divided along Republican-governor / Democratic-legislature lines, more often than not.

A cross-state econometric investigation, moreover, indicates that, keeping all other factors consistent, the discrepancy between a state's majority-party vote for the Republican gubernatorial candidate and the Republicans' portion of the state's lower legislative house is an increasing function with respect to the state tax percentage.

In total, at the federal and state government levels, a significant portion of the seemingly irrational behavior voters exhibit in the voting booth might actually have a perfectly rational explanation.

Feeding Frenzy`` (Henry Holt, over 300 pages, nearly $20), a highly detailed account of the Wedtech scandal, begins on a reassuring note.
Right at the beginning in the preface, co-author William Sternberg provides a single instance of his personal integrity.

When offered a complimentary journey from the Bronx, Wedtech's headquarters, to Washington, D.C., by one of Wedtech's main executives, he informs the reader, 'being cautious of accepting any significant gift from individuals I was covering, I refused.'
Any inquiry into the reason an author would find this poignant, idealistic memo of confidence essential is resolved through perusing this volume about sticky fingers and crafty swindlers.

Bribe after bribe, Mr. Sternberg and his sole collaborator, Matthew C. Harrison Jr., guided us along the journey Wedtech undertook, evolving from a modest manufacturing firm to a reputable defense contractor, charged with the crucial mission of manufacturing essential gear for both the Army and the Navy.
The book centers on John Mariotta, the founder of the company, and Fred Neuberger, who teamed up with him shortly following Wedtech's establishment.
Although it began in the mid-1960s, Wedtech didn't truly gain momentum until a decade later, in 1975, when Mr. Neuberger found the federal government's Section 8 A program for minority businesses.
This is a Johnson-era, Great Society creation that mandates several government contracts be awarded noncompetitively to minority businesses.
Mr. Neuberger realized that, despite his Italian heritage, Mr. Mariotta could still qualify as a minority individual given his birthplace in Puerto Rico.
The partners merely had to falsify the true ownership of the corporation.
Instead of an even split, it became, on paper only, two-fifths Mariotta, three-fifths Neuberger, and they were in the program and off to the races.

Wedtech, in addition to being a `` minority-owned business,`` was situated in the South Bronx, a severely distressed region, which gained notoriety during Jimmy Carter's election campaign for presidency in the late '70s.

The company plugged itself directly into the Carter campaign's talk of reconstructing the South Bronx and continued to exploit the minority -- South Bronx perspective throughout the Reagan era of the 1980s.

Beginning its dubious path with Congressman Mario Biaggi, currently imprisoned, the company embarked on a history of bribing numerous federal, state, and local public officials, as well as individuals connected to them, extending to and encompassing E. Robert Wallach, a close associate and counselor to the past Attorney General Ed Meese.
Wedtech did not merely employ traditional bribery tactics.

It made significant use of modern influence peddling techniques, retaining a number of politically connected 'respectable' law firms, investment bankers, and political consultants, including Reagan confidant Lyn Nofzinger.
When needed, it sought and received help from a criminal organization.
Occasionally, those who were bribed would become partners within the firm.
Wedtech's management has employed a merit-based system.
If you were particularly instrumental in a corrupt scheme, you received not just money in a sack, but also shares.
If you were not one of the top crooks, you found yourself out in the cold, a fate that ultimately befell Mr. Mariotta, the firm's sole 'minority' individual.
But despite the sensational nature of the revelations and the breezy, easy-to-read tabloid style, 'Feeding Frenzy' sometimes fails to captivate its readers.
Some of the scams displayed a fair amount of ingenuity: Auditors discovered fraud within the first few days of the job.
Wedtech's scammers merely bribed them to keep quiet.
The scammers themselves were garden-variety low lifes, prominent spenders seeking large mansions, several Mercedes cars, numerous attractive women, and pricey clothes.
Among the many of them, not a single one is wrestling with good and evil, or particularly intelligent or even momentarily insane.

The single character who was particularly intriguing was Irving Louis Lobsenz, a pediatrician who altered his name to Rusty Kent London and transitioned into a renowned gambler and author of a book on blackjack.
He enters the narrative at the conclusion, precisely when he is destined to be apprehended.

They do sometimes come around to saying that the courts might want to terminate `` inflexible affirmative action programs.``

Several balloon shows are held each year in the U.S., including the world's longest gathering of pseudo Phineas Fogg characters -- the ten-day Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta that draws over 750,000 fans and nearly 600 balloons, some cleverly designed to look like Carmen Miranda, Garfield, or a 15-story-high condom.
The condom balloon was denied entry status for the second time this year.
But in Epinal, a gray 17th-century river town adjacent to France's Vosges mountain region, few of these Yankee-come-lately enthusiasms for things aloft were evident.
Ballooning at the fashionable time of 5:30 a.m. retained the charm for many sunrise enthusiasts of root-canal work.
Feeling the constant naggings of a cultural obligation, I quickly signed up.
The primary thing anyone will tell you about ballooning is that it demands a certain level of athletic skill, or even a bit of daring.
So long as you look in any direction but down.
They might also inform you that despite your intense dislike for heights, you can still go up in a balloon.
I still say do not glance downwards.
Not when you're in the midst of ascending.
What they won't tell you is not to go aloft in anything you don't want to get soaked.
I'm not referring to a typical champagne drenching that occurs during the first back-on-terra-firma toast.
I'm talking about landing in the canal.
In a large porous wicker basket.
With a pilot who speaks very little English.
To wit, my sole journey and initiations referred to as virgins commenced at daybreak on a damp fairway and concluded by midday in a wet meadow.
Balloon flights frequently occur at dawn or dusk, when the winds are at their lightest.

In between came numerous cups of coffee drinking while watching the balloons inflate and numerous individuals standing around deciding who would fly in which balloon and in what sequence the baskets hold a maximum of three passengers.
When it wasn't my turn in the balloon, I followed its progress from the second chase car, listening to the driver holler into a walkie-talkie.

After long stretches of this attendant ground activity came nearly 30 delightful minutes of drifting above the Vosges watching the silver mists rise off the river and the French cows amble about the fields.
It's hard not to feel that God's in his heaven with this sort of panoramic view of the world, even if your pilot in a ridiculous plaid beret kept emphasizing how 'beautiful' it all was.
Ultimately, several French farmers and their spouses emerged from their stone dwellings, raising a pair of hands each to shield their small eyes and peered at us.
It's no surprise.
We were heading directly into their single canal.
Remember, the primary guideline in ballooning is that there's no way to navigate.
And neither can any pilot.
You can move either up or down by heating the balloon's air with a single propane burner, which does make the top of your head feel warm as you ride the gentle air currents.
Which makes the sole chase car essential.
Few balloonists rarely exceed 3,000 feet in altitude, while many travel at a relaxed pace of 6-8 miles per hour.
When the balloon is cruising along at a consistent height, there's almost no sense of movement.
Only when someone is ascending -- or in our instance descending just a bit too swiftly -- do they feel, quite frankly, like they're floating in a picnic basket.
What is that person doing? hissed my sole English-speaking companion, whose knuckles had turned pale.
You bet attention, I yelled back, leaping atop three propane tanks, 'I'm wearing my alligator loafers!'
Our pilot simply laughed, fired up the burner and with a powerful burst of flame lifted us, oh, about 10-inches above the water level.
We scuttled along for several meters before he plunged us into the drink once more.
Ultimately we arrived to rest in a damp patch of field where we experienced the exquisite pleasure of climbing out of the basket into the mud as the other half of our ballooning tag team climbed in.
I glanced at my timepiece.
Hardly a forty-five minutes in the air.
Back in the chase car, we drove around a few times more, got stuck in a ditch, enlisted the help of a nearby farmer to free the trailer hitch and pull us from the ditch.

We eventually met up with our balloon, which had landed on a dirt path, surrounded by a group of Epinalers who observed us taking apart our aircraft -- a full hour of non-flying tasks involving pulling the balloon down, deflating it, rolling it up, and packing both it and the basket into the trailer.
It was the most exercise we'd had all week and it was followed by our driving straight to the closest watering hole.
This meant returning to the golf course, where we observed several French duffers tackle the initial tee as we lounged under Cinzano umbrellas, me sipping an espresso and my ego.
A whole morning of ballooning and I had been off the ground for less than an hour.
Still, I figured the event's envy-factor back in the U.S.A. was almost without equal.
As for the ride back to camp, our pilot and several other French-speaking passengers clambered into the chase car.
My sole American companion and I were left to ride outdoors in the sole wicker basket.
As we swiftly passed by the lone gendarme, I couldn't help but rear up on my single soggy loafer and salute.
Ms. de Vries is one of the few free-lance writers.
A United Nations committee outlines a strategy to decrease emissions

The U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations -- gained renewed focus Friday with the release of a document outlining substantial greenhouse-gas reductions over the following 35 years, with industrialized nations bearing the brunt of the burden in the short term.

The text, which could provide the essential foundation for a ultimate political agreement to regulate greenhouse gases, pinpointed the few remaining obstacles as much as it shed light on a viable path forward.
But it was viewed as a crucial step in a negotiation rapidly approaching its deadline, with nearly 150 global leaders scheduled to arrive in Copenhagen the following week.

Forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group, the text does not specify the amount of funds that wealthy nations might allocate to underprivileged ones for addressing global warming in both the short and extended term.

And it provides several options for the key questions, encompassing how developed and major emerging economies would reduce their carbon output, and what the maximum limit of global temperature rise would be that policymakers could agree to tolerate.
It provides considerable flexibility to the process, said John Coequyt, the senior representative from Washington for the Sierra Club.

Michael Zammit Cutajar, who penned the seven-page document, condensed a 200-page negotiation text to concentrate on what the U.N.'s leading climate official, Yvo de Boer, termed as 'the overarching picture.'

It outlines a potential deal where industrial nations aim to collectively reduce emissions by 2030 by 20 to 40 percent from 1990 levels, whereas leading developing countries plan to cut theirs by 10 to 25 percent over the same timeframe.
Collectively, the countries aim to reduce emissions by 45 to 90 percent by the year 2050.

The European Union also injected momentum into the talks on Friday, committing to allocate $4.5 billion annually for the following three years to assist underprivileged nations in responding to the effects of climate change -- ranging from managing floods and droughts to preventing deforestation.
Still, Friday featured the similar sort of verbal fireworks that have dominated the talks for the past few days.

U.S. special climate envoy Todd Stern dismissed language mandating binding cuts of greenhouse-gas emissions from two industrialized countries as opposed to voluntary measures by several major emerging economies unless they received funding from developed nations.
The move indicated that the Obama administration is pursuing a tougher stance on China than the Bush administration did merely three years prior.

The United States is not going to strike a deal unless several key developing countries step forward and take action, stated Stern, who further griped that the text failed to adequately ensure the cuts could be confirmed by independent observers.

Stern made his comments a few hours after the Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei stated that America's lead climate negotiator was either missing "common sense" or was "highly imprudent" in his statement earlier in the week, claiming that the United States would offer no financial assistance to China in addressing global warming.
With the future economic trajectory of several major global powers at stake, conflicts have emerged both among various developing regions and between industrialized nations and burgeoning economies.

The ongoing struggle is as much about rescuing several economies as preserving the planet, with China and the United States disputing their specific responsibilities while numerous poorer nations assert that the globe's ten most powerful countries are neglecting the scientific necessity for more aggressive action.

Ricardo Ulate, a Costa Rican delegate, stated it's predictable that several powerful nations are debating whose responsibility it is to cover the expenses of limiting greenhouse gases, despite numerous fragile countries increasingly taking bold steps to make the large polluters responsible for their deeds.

This is undoubtedly a game in which a potential economic hegemony is being fostered, noted Ulate, who also functions as the senior Mexico and Central America climate change adviser for Conservation International.

A few of the countries most susceptible to the effects of climate change suggested they will persist in advocating for a legally binding treaty in Copenhagen, despite several key participants believing the negotiations are likely to yield only a political agreement at maximum.
The Alliance of Small Island States, which is composed of over 40 members, drafted a 20-page treaty proposal late Thursday night.

Artur Runge-Metzger, who leads international climate negotiations on behalf of the European Commission, stated that the campaign by numerous island countries has `` exerted political pressure on the whole political process, `` partly due to their newfound unity and insistence on action from major emerging economies including China and India.
The talks took on new urgency as delegates focused on the fact that they must resolve several of the outstanding issues before the heads of government arrive to strike a deal.

High-level officials including the Indian environment minister Jairam Ramesh and several Chinese ministers disembarked from multiple planes and hurried through the Bella Center's numerous halls towards confidential meetings and press briefings, aiming to establish claims that will undergo arbitration in the coming days.

The vast expanse of the gathering -- where several thousand people flow in and out of the convention center daily, guitar-strumming activists stage nightly performances satirizing the nations they believe are compromising, and draft proposals circulate on paper instead of electronically -- presents a challenge.
The intensity is merely escalating: approximately all crucial ministers have arrived, and by Wednesday 70 heads of state are expected in Copenhagen.
We're joining the major leagues, said Carlos Manuel Rodriguez, vice president for international policy at Conservation International.
Several heavyweights are approaching.

The issue assesses various types of damage inflicted upon the sporting spirit.

Arsenic-tolerant microbes increase the likelihood of discovering additional types of life on Earth, or beyond
The discovery of a bizarre bacteria that can utilize arsenic as a crucial nutrient expands the potential scope for discovering numerous new forms of life on Earth and perhaps even further.
While researchers discovered the unique bacteria here on Earth, they suggest it demonstrates that life may have numerous possibilities beyond the few elements previously thought to be essential.
This organism possesses a pair of capabilities.
It can grow with both phosphorus and arsenic.

That makes it rather peculiar, though it falls short of being a truly 'alien' form of life, commented Paul C. W. Davies of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report featured in the latest online edition of the journal Science on Thursday.
Several key elements are traditionally crucial for life - carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
But the researchers discovered that the bacteria, found in Mono Lake, Calif., can continue growing even after replacing phosphorus with arsenic.
It makes one wonder what other possibilities exist, said Ariel D. Anbar of Arizona State University, a contributing author to the report.
The discovery is crucial in the quest for extraterrestrial life as researchers must possess the ability to identify what life might resemble, Anbar stated.
The study centers on the numerous microbes present on Earth.

However, the sole announcement of a news conference to discuss it, which did not reveal specifics of the find, sparked extensive speculation across the Internet that the upcoming report might unveil the discovery of extraterrestrial life.

The discovery suggests that in numerous planetary environments organisms could potentially utilize various elements to sustain biochemistry, indicating that the 'canonical' set of elements we believe to be indispensable for life may not be as immutable, commented Charles Cockell, a professor at the Planetary and Space Sciences Research Institute, Open University, in Milton Keynes, United Kingdom.
Cockell was not a member of any research team.
It wasn't just a random discovery.
Felisa Wolfe-Simon of NASA's Astrobiology Institute, who was the principal investigator of the study, focused on Mono Lake due to its elevated arsenic concentrations.
Arsenic and phosphorus are chemically similar, so she speculated that some microbes exposed to both might be able to substitute one for the other.
Arsenic is poisonous primarily due to its chemical properties being akin to those of phosphorus.
As a consequence, many organisms struggle to differentiate between these elements.
But arsenic is significantly different, working less effectively than phosphorus; it infiltrates and tends to clog the mechanisms of our biochemical machinery, explained Anbar.
The researchers gathered several strains of the bacteria known as GFAJ-1 and exposed them to varying concentrations of arsenic, to which they were able to adapt and thrive.

The microbe does grow better on phosphorus, but demonstrating its ability to thrive with arsenic instead raises the chance that life forms utilizing arsenic might occur naturally, either in other locations on Earth or on a different planet or moon where arsenic is more prevalent.

Jamie S. Foster, an assistant professor of microbiology at the University of Florida, said the concept that arsenic might replace phosphorus isn't novel, although no single instance has demonstrated its effectiveness thus far.
Arsenic was several times more common in the early epochs of Earth, she said, which led researchers to speculate that primitive life forms might have utilized it.
It does suggest that there might be numerous ways to form life, beyond just the one way life formed on early Earth,' said Foster, who was not a member of Wolfe-Simon's research team.
The research was backed by NASA, two other departments, including the Department of Energy and the National Institutes of Health.

Support for democracy in various regions of Latin America is gradually increasing, much like the growing support for private businesses.
Crime has become a major concern compared to the issue of unemployment.

Those are some of the findings from the most recent Latinobarómetro poll conducted in a dozen countries and published exclusively by The Economist.
Because the poll has been conducted every two years since the mid-1990s, it monitors shifts in attitude throughout the region.
Several related factors are prominent in the outcomes of this year's poll, conducted in September and the initial days of October.
The primary aspect is Latin America's predominantly sunny mood.
The primary factor is the enhanced stability of attitudes towards democracy and its key institutions.
Support for democracy has increased significantly in a few countries on the Pacific coast of South America.
For example in Peru, where economic growth has averaged 5% a year since 2002, support for democracy has increased from a low of 35% in 2005 to nearly 60% this year.
It also increased in Mexico, where the economy has rebounded following a significant decline in output the previous year.
But approximately a third of respondents in Mexico and Brazil, the region's two most populous countries, are strong democrats, which affects the regional average (see chart 2).

Nearly half of the respondents throughout the region declared contentment with their country's democratic practices, matching the previous year's percentage and showing a substantial rise from the 30% recorded in 2001 (chart 3).

Around a third said they had confidence in their country's Congress and nearly half in their government, similar to the previous year's figures of 34% and 45% respectively, a significant increase from the percentages in 2003 (17% and 24%).
Several years ago, economic troubles in Latin America weakened support for democracy.
That it has held up during the global financial turmoil is likely due to the fact that several Latin American nations endured a short-lived recession and have since experienced a robust recovery.
Furthermore, a more robust social safety net has aided in protecting numerous poor individuals.

The United Nations' Economic Commission for Latin America reported this week that the percentage of Latin Americans living in poverty increased slightly in 2009 and has decreased once more this year, to approximately 30%.
But the mood differs considerably between each country ( see chart 3 ) .
Brazil's robust economic performance and the high popularity of its outgoing president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, are evident in an extensively felt sense of advancement.
That is rare in Mexico and Central America, where the recession was quite severe and violent crime has significantly increased.

For the first time since the polls started, a majority of respondents throughout Latin America collectively identify crime, not unemployment, as the primary issue affecting their country (see chart 4).
About a third say that either they or a close relative have been victims of crime in the last year, which is a decrease from nearly 40% the previous year and represents the lowest figure since 1995.

A more robust economic performance is reflected in increasing backing for private enterprise and the market economy: approximately 70% of respondents throughout the region assert that private enterprise is crucial for development, an increase from 55% in 2007 (see chart 6).

Scalia, Thomas, and a few other justices dine with several healthcare law challengers as the court reviews the case

The day the Supreme Court assembled in private to deliberate on the politically charged question of whether to review a challenge against President Obama's healthcare law, several of its justices, including Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, attended a dinner hosted by the law firm that is set to present the case to the high court.
The occasion was last Thursday, when the eight justices met for a conference to pour over several petitions for review.

Several of the cases at issue included a suit filed by over two dozen states contesting the comprehensive healthcare overhaul approved by Congress the previous year, a law which has served as a unifying cause for conservative activists across the country.

The justices agreed to hear the suit; indeed, a substantial 6-hour argument is anticipated in March, and the result is poised to shake up the 2012 presidential race, which will be at its peak by the time the court's decision is handed down.
The sole lawyer set to appear before the court and contend that the law be discarded is presumably Paul Clement, who held the position of U.S. solicitor general under the George W. Bush era.

Clement's law firm, Bancroft PLLC, was one of nearly thirty firms that contributed to sponsoring the annual dinner of the Federalist Society, a long-standing group committed to promoting conservative legal principles.
Yet another firm that sponsored the dinner, Jones Day, represents one of several trade associations that challenged the law, the National Federation of Independent Business.
A different sponsor was the pharmaceutical conglomerate Pfizer Inc, which holds a substantial financial stake in the result of the litigation.
The dinner was held at a hotel in Washington a few hours following the court's conference about the case.
In attendance were several individuals, including Mitch McConnell, the Senate's leading Republican and a confirmed opponent of the healthcare law.
The two prominent guests at the dinner were Scalia and Thomas.
It's a common occurrence: The justices have been participating in Federalist Society events for decades.
And it's not anything that runs afoul of ethical guidelines.
In fact, several justices are exempt from the Code of Conduct that governs the actions of other federal justices.

If they did, they arguably fell under code's Canon 5D, which states, `` A judge may attend fund-raising events for up to two law-related and other organizations although the judge may not be a speaker, a guest of honor, or featured on the program of such an event. ``

Nevertheless, the close proximity of Scalia and Thomas to several law firms involved in the case, and also to a company holding a substantial financial interest, was sufficient to concern government ethics activists.
Several justices were wining and dining at a formal fundraiser with a group of attorneys who have multiple cases pending before the court.
Their consistent appearance and substantial assistance in fundraising for this event undermines any claims of impartiality, and is thus unacceptable.
Scalia and Thomas have demonstrated minimal regard for critics who argue they frequently blend the business of the court with politically motivated groups like the Federalist Society.
And one of Thomas' wives, Ginni, is a prominent conservative activist.
Moreover, conservatives contend it's Justice Elena Kagan who possesses the ethical issue, unlike Scalia and only one other justice.
Kagan served as solicitor general in the Obama administration when several legal challenges to the law were brought at the trial court level.
Her critics have urged Kagan to recuse herself from the case's hearing, arguing that her substantial involvement in defending the law at that time precludes her from being impartial now.
Kagan has provided little indication she will take such action.

Are immigrants a handful of burdens or a multitude of opportunities for the economy?

Immigration policy under Nicolas Sarkozy faced criticism on numerous fronts, including an overload of police, legal, and administrative services due to a quota-based policy and the consistency of that policy with the self-proclaimed title of the nation as the protector of French human rights.

Recently, the administrative harassment targeting international students has been a focal point, as the interior minister ('Libération' on May 23) stated that France 'is not seeking additional foreign talent, bricklayers, or waiters.'
But it is frequently analyzed from the economic viewpoint.
There is considerable consensus between the Left and the Right regarding this subject.

On the Right, the tone was set by Jacques Chirac, who declared in 1976 that `` nearly a million unemployed would not become a problem in a country with over 1.5 million foreign workers, `` and on the Left by Michel Rocard explaining in 1990 that France `` cannot accommodate the bulk of the world's misery.``
The primary difference, the extent of generosity
In the early 2000s, the concern over the potential incursion into national territory by numerous Polish plumbers was shared by both political Left and Right sides.
Many sides view immigrants as a burden on the French economy and French society.
The significant difference lies in the level of generosity, that some are willing to extend to immigrants.
In his program, François Hollande limits his discussion to trivialities, suggesting that mutual growth could resolve our immigration issue.
This concept of immigration as a significant burden and a major problem might be an electoral advantage, yet it entails high economic costs.

As the economists Ian Goldin and Geoffrey Cameron remind us in their latest book synthesizing extensive knowledge on immigration ('Exceptional People: How Migration Shaped Our World and Will Define Our Future', May 2011, Princeton University Press, over 300 pages), the vast majority of specialists agree on the beneficial influence of migration patterns on economic expansion, salaries, and job opportunities in nations that receive immigrants.
Curbing immigration results in minimal growth and negatively impacts employment.

Fears concerning the influence of immigrant groups are grounded in the belief that they tend to displace a significant number of native workers, especially those who are unskilled, thus applying downward pressure on salary levels.
But experience demonstrates that, in reality, immigrants are far more complementary than replacements to local labor, particularly in trades suffering from a severe shortage of local workers.

Unskilled immigrants are employed in numerous sectors, which typically do not entice domestic labor or the majority of highly skilled individuals in vibrant sectors where training is not associated with job offers.
A significant impact on wages

In a similar fashion to how a surgeon might struggle in a nation lacking even a single anaesthetist, the synergies between residents and immigrant groups lead to the phenomenon where the incoming immigrants positively impact the salaries of native workers.
Giovanni Peri has estimated that a 2% increase in the migratory flow leads to a rise in real long-term pay of between 1.2 and 1.8 %.

And does so without taking into account the fact that the immense diversity contributed by immigrants significantly adds to the creation of ideas and economic expansion ( a significant number of naturalised immigrants are counted among American Nobel prize winners, and companies like Google, Intel, Paypal, eBay, and Yahoo have immigrant founders ) .
Migrants are significant net contributors to social systems, typically contributing around 5% of the total budgets across European countries.

The World Labor Organisation estimates that, for instance, in Germany, an immigrant arriving at the age of 25, will make a net contribution (receipts minus expenditure) of roughly 100,000 Euros to public budgets over their lifetime.
Nicolas Sarkozy aimed at the beginning of his term to seek out several missing areas of growth 'with determination.'
The teeth in question, meant to deter several immigrants, had exactly the reverse effect.

Alimta is a substance that is converted into a single solution for infusion ( administered drop by drop into a vein ).
It contains an active substance, pemetrexed.
How is Alimta typically utilized?
Alimta is utilized in the treatment of several forms of cancer, including pleural mesothelioma, a cancer affecting the lining of the lungs typically triggered by exposure to asbestos.

Alimta is employed alongside cisplatin (a different anticancer agent) when the tumor is inoperable (cannot be excised by surgery solely) and aggressive (has disseminated, or is prone to disseminate readily, to additional areas of the body), in individuals who have not undergone chemotherapy (cancer treatments) preceding the development of advanced or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer that doesn't involve squamous cells.

Alimta is used in conjunction with cisplatin for patients who have not undergone prior treatment, and as a standalone therapy for patients who have had prior exposure to a different form of chemotherapy.
The medication is obtainable solely upon presentation of a prescription.
How is Alimta typically used?
Alimta should solely be administered under the direction of a medical professional proficient in the application of cancer-fighting chemotherapy.
The typical dose of Alimta is 450 mg per square meter of body surface area ( calculated using the patient's height and weight ).
It is administered every four weeks via intravenous infusion, which lasts for 15 minutes.

To minimize side effects, patients are advised to ingest a corticosteroid and folic acid (a form of vitamin), as well as receive periodic injections of vitamin B12 throughout their treatment with Alimta.

When Alimta is administered alongside cisplatin, a single anti-emetic medication (to hinder vomiting) and adequate fluids (to forestall dehydration) need to be administered either prior to or following the single cisplatin dosage.
Treatment may need to be postponed or halted, or the dosage decreased, in patients with abnormal blood levels or experiencing various alternative side effects.
Alimta is not recommended for patients suffering from mild to severe kidney issues.
For further details, refer to the Product Characteristics Summary (which is also a section of the EPAR).
How does Alimta function?

The primary active substance in Alimta, pemetrexed, acts as a cytotoxic agent (an agent that eliminates cells in the process of division, including cancer cells), categorizing it within the class of antimetabolites.

In the body, pemetrexed is transformed into its active form, which inhibits the function of enzymes responsible for synthesizing nucleotides—the fundamental components of DNA and RNA, crucial genetic materials within cells.
How extensively has Alimta been studied?
For the treatment of malignant pleural mesothelioma, Alimta has been studied in a primary trial involving 500 patients who had not undergone chemotherapy for their disease previously.
The effects of Alimta combined with two drugs, including cisplatin, were compared to the effects of cisplatin as a single treatment.

For the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, the effects of Alimta were compared with those of docetaxel (another anticancer medicine) in a study involving over 500 patients with locally advanced or metastatic disease who had previously undergone chemotherapy.

Alimta was also compared with gemcitabine ( another anticancer medicine ) , both in combination with cisplatin , in a study involving over 1,700 patients who had not received chemotherapy for lung cancer previously .
In each of the studies, the primary measure of effectiveness was the duration of patient survival.
What benefits have been shown by Alimta in numerous studies?
Alimta has extended the life expectancy for many patients suffering from malignant pleural mesothelioma.
Patients receiving Alimta and cisplatin survived for an average of ten months, compared with eight months in those receiving cisplatin alone.
In patients who had undergone chemotherapy previously, the average survival duration was approximately 9 months with Alimta, as opposed to roughly 8 months with docetaxel.
In patients who had not received chemotherapy previously, the average survival period was approximately 9.5 months across the two groups.

However, in each of the two studies, patients whose cancer was not affecting squamous cells experienced extended survival periods when treated with Alimta, as opposed to those receiving the comparator.
In contrast, patients whose cancer was affecting squamous cells typically had reduced survival times when treated with Alimta.

What are the multiple uses of Cerenia?
Cerenia is one of the anti-emetics, this means that it prevents nausea and vomiting.
It is commonly used in canines to prevent episodes of vomiting, including those caused by chemotherapy drugs (some cancer treatment medications that are widely recognized to induce vomiting).

In conjunction with various supportive measures like additional veterinary treatments or a unique diet, Cerenia may also be employed for treating vomiting (whether it's an injection alone or an injection preceding tablet intake).

Cerenia blocks several neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptors, which act in the central nervous system.

Several studies with Cerenia were conducted in laboratory dogs or in animal patients at veterinary practices in a few European countries and in the USA.

The treatment for a vomiting dog should begin with an injection, because some animals might not retain a single tablet (as they could potentially regurgitate the whole tablet again).
For ongoing treatment, the pet owner may give the three tablets to the dog daily.
Also, the treatment of vomiting should merely be accompanied by additional supportive measures or alternative veterinary therapies when addressing the underlying causes of the vomiting.
What are the risks associated with Cerenia?
Cerenia was generally well tolerated when administered daily at dosages up to 4 times the recommended doses for an extended period (up to 2 times the recommended maximum duration of treatment).
